Description: Make sure that you land in the right team
Pros: - Great place for building new technologies from scratch since most technologies used within Apple are homegrown. - Great WLB if you are a junior engineer. - Awesome campus and great food (which is not free but cheaper compared to restaurants outside). - Compensation hikes are decent partly due to bonus at the end of every year and partly because of constant stock appreciation. - Career progression is super fast if you are lucky enough to find a good manager. - Overall people are nice to each other and like to help each other. There is no stack ranking (officially), so you wonâ€™t find backstabbers in your team too often. - Free Avis premium membership which saves you a lot money on rental cars if you like traveling.
Cons: - Career progression path might not be clear if you are stuck in an unimportant team with a manager who is not respected by the leadership. - There arenâ€™t a lot of free perks. Food is not free. Snacks are limited. - Top down decision making with little to no focus on the voice of lower level engineers. - Culture of secrecy which makes it difficult to know about or contribute to technologies other teams are working on. - Extremely stressful life with really bad WLB and too many meetings if you are a mid level manager of an important team. Also, WLB is not great for people who take more responsibility and are higher up on the career ladder. - Internal team switches are extremely difficult and is generally not encouraged.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee T***** Software Engineer - Mar 22, 2022

Description: Great, if you'd give it your soul
Pros: * good comp* leadership and stock price have proven track record* nice office (Apple Park, at least)* decent benefits* opportunities to innovate and/or seize initiative and lead surprisingly common* your work usually ships (as opposed to getting canceled)* seemingly little bureaucracy involved in promotions (you help your manager who knows you build you a case)
Cons: * culty vibes that everything we do is groundbreaking; cult-like love (possibly feigned) for our products is almost mandatory* officially, you can't own outside software projects built on your own hardware + time; can't ship them to the App Store (only internal release)* low pto* poor work-life balance encouraged by culture, if not by deliverables schedule* poor documentation + lots of custom tooling/practices + information being siloed by org/disclosures/etc. makes it relatively hard to get things done without developing a set of skills highly specific to Apple (ie, non-transferable)* usually several stakeholders involved on projects and it's tough to get everyone on board* surprisingly little enforcement of or incentives for best practices in swe (testing, etc.)* lots to learn but no time budgeted in deliverables schedule to learn, so you would need to do so on your own time or be mediocre* kinda sterile, measured corporate culture; we act like the world is watching our every move... and they are

Description: Solid place for fans of the brand
Pros: The people who work here are really good workers, so much to learn from coworkers. Brand name is cool in and outside of the valley professionally and among non professional circles.
Cons: Poor work life balance. There is a lot of talk about wellness and then at the same time if you try to establish some boundaries you are looked down upon, labeled as difficult to reach, and feel major judgment for trying to have a life that is not Apple related. LOTS of post 6pm working hours and meetings, and LOTS of weekends. Experiences at the company is highly variable between teams and orgs. Top down culture emphasizes working extra hard and putting in sacrifices for the developing the best products on earth. There is a phrase with your job at Apple you need two other jobs so thatâ€™s that. Doing your job gets you a below expectations mark. Doing extra effort and crazy hours gets you achieved expectations mark. Doing two jobs worth of work gets you exceeded expectations mark. For the frequency of record profits, Apple can definitely pay more in comp and employee benefits.

Cons: The entire company culture can be described as opaque. This leads to friction, missed opportunities, etc. Career progression is completely opaque and essentially up to your management: I have a good relationship with my manager and still found it necessary to leave to achieve my career goals. Teams are very lean. Getting resources/time for projects can be very difficult, as many teams are highly impacted by other deliverables and unable to provide even minimal support without exec level backing.  This is exacerbated by a degenerate project management structure.People stay in their lane. There are many experts and few generalists. This is a pro and a con. There is definite entrenched group think in parts, but also a wealth of knowledge and experience.

Description: Good and Impactful Work, Collaborative Culture with Good co-workers. Benefits and Comp trail a few other FAANGMs...
Pros: (SWE) at Apple. Good place to work overall. Good, impactful projects, always working on something that will ship (no wasted work or busy work), so have a good sense of accomplishment. Collaborative culture, with good co-workers. The entire culture is based on collaboration (unlike some other FAANGMs where the culture is cutthroat and competitive). Good WLB (this one was a bit of a surprise for me, I expected bad WLB). Everyone is very respectful of weekends. No work after 6 PM.Overall, recommended as a place to work.
Cons: Comp and benefits are in the middle of the FAANGM pack. Total Comp at FB is measurably higher. Total Comp at Google is comparable to slightly better than Apple. And Apple TC seems better than Amazon and Microsoft for sure. Growth at Apple is hard and transition between levels could take years and years.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee m***** Software Engineer - Sep 7, 2021

Pros: TDG is developing lots of exciting things and it's interesting to be involved with them.I'm grateful for the salary and the reputation Apple has, it's great on a resume.
Cons: Secrecy is so severe, I'm almost always left in the dark, and lack information on how to do my job effectively. This is true for managers as well. My boss is constantly asking me if I know about X or Y other team, what exactly they are working on, how we can best collaborate with them, or what their timelines are. If my boss doesn't know, how should I know?I have a rough overall picture, but I'm missing exact details about what other teams are doing. I've got 50+ top secret disclosures in the company and still I don't know what our closest collaborators are doing besides the tiny trickle of information they give us. This leads to a really toxic culture where managers are able to lie through their teeth at one another about how great their teams are and what they're working on. Because nobody actually knows anything there's no way to verify any claims. This goes vertically as well. Managers tend to lie to upper management about any problems or lack of velocity on things, until eight months go by and it turns into a huge problem. If the company was more honest and transparent with itself these issues wouldn't arise. It's really absurd, and an awful way to run an organization.  It can feel like you're working on an assembly line just focusing on your small part of the problem, without any exposure to the greater picture. This is extremely demoralizing. Also, TDG tends to hire senior developers and then put them in junior roles where everything is top-down, and you're not given any freedom to think for yourself.

Pros: - Slightly higher pay compared to other big tech companies- prestige(?)- discount on apple products
Cons: Note: this is for a virtual internship.- Very secretive, feels like being discouraged to contact other people in other teams because each employee has their own level of clearance.- Team members felt very aloof and silent. Even during small virtual meetings (< 5 people), none of the members turn on their videos so we're just blank boxes talking to each other.- Cannot freely ask basic technical questions to other people outside the team since most of the technical group chats are private. Since I can only ask team members, and they're also busy, the response time is not great.- The recruiting team feels very disorganized and quiet (almost no communication pre-internship and during the internship itself). Even basic information such as full-time conversion is not communicated unless specifically asked.- There's no internal documentation (or very rare) and no style guide for coding, so the codebase is very hard to read and understand for people new to the team. Each employee also only has clearance to 1-2 codebases related to the project, so we cannot see other team's codes for reference/example.

Pros: Been at apple as a HW engineer for a few years. Its work-life balance is really not as bad as many aapl engineer would like to say. Apple is also a great place to build and horn your skills (technical, communication, etc..) , at least for HW engineers. Due to the size and demand of the company's products, lots of apple's suppliers are willing to share their know-how with you. As anyone who has been HW industry for a while, this is really valuable and something you would not have access to otherwise
Cons: While it's a great place to build your skill (from HW engi. perspective), you get bored once you learned.

Description: Interesting work but incredibly silo'd (by design), secretive, and flat.
Pros: - The comp is pretty good between the RSUs and ESPP (up to 10% pre-tax). - Expanding Austin campus is very nice, Silicon Valley amenities with the Texas cost of living, supposedly only a 10% comp adjustment which is more than made up for with the state income tax difference alone (although property taxes are high in Texas, homes are affordable and new/nice).- If you are an Apple fan it can feel like a dream come true.- Easy to get the tools you need for the job (hardware or software)- Culture still allows for moving fast and quite a bit less bureaucracy than similar sized companies.- Adapted well to remote work during Covid, will almost certainly have more remote options post-covid.
Cons: - The employee discount is weak.- You MUST be a hardcore Apple fan to make it. (may be a pro or con depending on your PoV)- A lot of internal political battles going on between the old guard (Steve's people) and newer folks who may not be as heavily invested in the culture of secrecy and speed.- Its a flat organization and can be difficult to advance or get headcount.- The silo'd nature of the company means it can be difficult to understand how your piece fits into the bigger picture.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee J***** Data Scientist - Dec 1, 2020

Description: Great pay, growth, challenging work and an inspirational workplace, albeit with a poor culture and WLB in some orgs.
Pros: Great pay and perksGrowth opportunities in terms of RSUs and careerGood work, challengesInspirational workplace, although the last few product releases have been rather insipid.
Cons: An expectation that you should be honored to work hard for them and should come to not only expect this, but wear it as a badge of honor. We were told at our orientation that they work hard and pride themselves on it. Frequently my managers joke about having worked the weekend or late hours and how their families had to cope with it.A top-down management style, where your managers and their managers have a lot of sway over what you do. Often times we have work coming from god knows where and are simply told it has to be done by so and so time. Let alone being involved in the feature set, we're not even brought in to discuss timelines. If it feels ridiculous, at best you can whine to your manager who'd put on a sympathetic face but you know they can't and won't go push back anywhere.Team bonding is non-existent, especially in some orgs. can't remember the last time we went to lunch together (when I asked my to-be-manager at my interview if they did team lunches, he just shrugged it off - everyone's too busy). The idea of pair programming is laughable, considering how much each of us handles. There's barely any bouncing ideas, we're all sandboxed in our own worlds and trying to get our work done. I'm sure it's better at other orgs though, but then moving teams here at Apple is notoriously painful.

Cons: - There's a large population of highly talented employees, and limited opportunities for rotations or other work from home positions to move into. Author Info: Verified User Current Employee y***** Senior Software Development Engineer - Aug 16, 2020

Description: You will be trading your life and time for money; But it could be highly rewarding if you work in the right team
Pros: - Apple hires some of the smartest so you are always in the company of brilliant people.- There are lot of opportunities to move around and take on different roles. Most managers are supportive and facilitate this. - Good compensation. - It is a paradise for Apple fanboys (I happened to be one).
Cons: - The team I worked in was understaffed all the time and that lead to poor work life balance as I had to spread myself and cover for deficencies. I saw this happen in all the teams and this wasn't a personal thing. - More execution heavy and less opportunities to influence and shape the consumer facing aspects of the product, unless you are higher up and in right teams. - The IS&T org that I worked in had lot of bureaucracy. Since 80% of the work in that org is done using contractors, getting high quality work done is a constant struggle. Most of my time and energy went in baby sitting contractor teams of B/C players and resolving in-fighting, which sucks the soul out of you.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee r***** Systems Design Engineer - May 21, 2020

Description: "Great company with a culture that takes getting used to"
Pros: One thing Iâ€™ve learned from talking to people within Apple is your experience will greatly vary, depending on your organization. Iâ€™m a software engineer in the Core OS organization within SWE, so my review only applies to that.People outside Apple like to poke fun when senior leadership publicly says theyâ€™re trying to be customer-centric and do the right thing while making decisions that go in to products. After being here, I truly believe that is the case! Tim and Craig have proven to be very thoughtful, honest and effective leadersWe work on some tough technical problems and some really innovative technology.At the end of the day, as an individual contributor I am enabled to put my head down and do my best work. Apple can be demanding, expect to receive emails and pings on nights and weekends. You have to learn to set boundaries and stick to them. If you enjoy your work, like I do, itâ€™s very easy to accidentally put too many hours in
Cons: As with lots of tech companies, there are many different personalities to deal with and some can make your job miserable. It sounds like being in middle management is extremely political and there are management movements / re-orgs pretty often.Apple culture can be difficult to navigate for some. Thereâ€™s very little documentation (this is improving), and the company is entirely built on making relationships and hallway conversations. This can make working in remote offices difficult, from what Iâ€™ve heard. Introverts beware!
Author Info: Verified User Current Employee B***** Software Engineer - May 16, 2020

Description: Overall a great company, but NO WLB

Cons: Zero work-life balance guaranteed. You always work longer than expected, work-life balance pretty much nonexistent. It is hard to get promoted even though you work really hard.
